'''[[Twenty-seventh Dynasty of Egypt]]''' as [[Pharaoh]] [[Cambyses II of Persia|Cambyses II]]. |- |align=center|[[535 BCE]]||align=center| || style="background:#fee;"|[[Cyrus the Great]] conquers the [[Gandhara Kingdom]] |- |align=center|[[539 BCE]]||align=center| || style="background:#fee;"|[[Cyrus the Great]] conquers the [[Neo-Babylonian Empire]] |- |align=center|[[543 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[King]] [[Vijaya of Sri Lanka|Vijaya]] establishes the '''[[Kingdom of Lanka]]''' and makes [[Tambapanni]] the new capital. |- |align=center|[[546 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Cyrus the Great]] conquers the [[Lydia|Lydian Empire]] |- |align=center|[[546 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Cyrus the Great]] establishes the '''[[Achaemenid Empire|Persian Empire]]''' and makes [[Pasargadae]] the new capital. |- |align=center|[[586 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|Traditional date for the destruction of the [[Kingdom of Judah]] at the hands of the Babylonians. |- |align=center|[[605 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|With the [[Battle of Carchemish]], the Assyrian Empire is destroyed and replaced by a balance of power between [[Babylon]], [[Medes|Media]], [[Lydia]] and [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. |- |align=center|[[609 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Harran]], the new capital of Assyria, is destroyed by the Medes and Babylonians |- |align=center|[[612 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Nineveh]] falls to a coalition of the Medes and Babylonians |- |align=center|[[650 BCE]]|||| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Ancient Carthage]] is established |- |align=center|[[653 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|After the [[Battle of Ulai]], [[Elam]] is vassalized by the Assyrians |- |align=center|[[657 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Byzantium]] is settled by colonists from [[Megara]] |- |align=center|[[660 BCE]]||align=center|February 11|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Emperor Jimmu]] establishes the '''[[History of Japan|Empire of Japan]]'''. |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|about 664 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Necho I]] establishes the '''[[Twenty-sixth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Sais]] is the capital. |- |align=center|[[671 BCE]]|||| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Esarhaddon]] captures [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] and drives the [[Kingdom of Kush|Kushites]] out of [[Lower Egypt]], and establishes local rulers in the delta region. |- |align=center|[[694 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Deioces]] is elected the first [[Median empire|King of the '''Medes''']]. [[Ecbatana]] (now [[Hamadan]]) is the capital. |- |align=center|[[695 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Gordium]], capital of [[Phrygia]], is destroyed by the [[Cimmerians]], resulting in Phrygia being ruled by the Lydians |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|about 700 BCE|| style="background:#eef;"|[[Phoenicians]] establish a colony in [[Malta]] with [[Mdina|Maleth]] as capital. |- |align=center|[[705 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|The capital of Assyria moves from Dur-Sharrukin to [[Nineveh]]. |- |align=center|[[706 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|The capital of Assyria moves from Nimrud to [[Dur-Sharrukin]]. |- |align=center|[[713 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|The Neo-Hittite states of [[Tabal]] and [[Hilakku]] fall to the Assyrians |- |align=center|[[717 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|The Neo-Hittite state of [[Carchemish]] falls to the Assyrians |- |align=center|[[720 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|Traditional date for the destruction of the [[Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)|Kingdom of Israel]] at the hands of the Assyrians |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|about 728 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Tefnakhte]] establishes the '''[[Twenty-fourth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Sais]] becomes the capital. |- |align=center|[[732 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|The Assyrians conquer Damascus, ending the kingdom of [[Aram-Damascus]]. |- |align=center|[[733 BCE]]-[[734 BCE]]|||| style="background:#eef;"|The city of [[Syracuse, Sicily]] is founded by settlers from Corinth and Tenea. |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|about 740 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Nubia|Nubian King]] [[Piye]] establishes the '''[[Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt]]''' and rules [[Egypt]] from [[Napata]] in [[Nubia]]. |- |align=center|[[745 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Tiglath-Pileser III]] founds the [[Neo-Assyrian Empire]], annexing the city of [[Babylon]] |- |align=center|[[753 BCE]]||align=center|April 21|| style="background:#eef;"|[[Romulus]] establishes the '''[[King of Rome|Kingdom of Rome]]'''. The new city of Rome becomes the capital. |- |align=center|[[808 BCE]]|||| style="background:#eef;"|[[Karanus]] establishes the '''[[Argead Dynasty of Macedon]]''' and builds [[Vergina#Archaeological finds|Aigai]] to be the capital. |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|about 875 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Pedubast I]] establishes the '''[[Twenty-third Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]] is the capital of '''[[Upper Egypt]]'''. |- |align=center|[[879 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Ashurnasirpal II]] moves the capital of the '''[[New Assyrian Empire]]''' to [[Kalhu]]. |- |align=center|[[911 BCE]]|||| style="background:#fee;"|[[Adad-nirari II]] establishes the '''[[New Assyrian Empire]]'''. [[Assur]] remains the capital. |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|about 930 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|The '''[[Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)|Kingdom of Israel]]''' under [[Jeroboam I]] separates from the '''[[Kingdom of Judah]]''' under [[Rehoboam]]. [[Samaria]] becomes the capital of Israel, [[Jerusalem]] remains the capital of Judah. |- | style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|about 945 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Shoshenq I]] establishes the '''[[Twenty-second Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Tanis]] remains the capital. |} ===Second Millennium BCE=== {|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !style="width:5%"|Year||style="width:95%"|Event |- |align=center|about 1004 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[King]] [[David]] conquers the city of [[Jebusite|Jebus]] and makes the renamed [[City of David]] (now [[Jerusalem]]) the capital of the '''[[United Kingdom of Israel and Judah]]'''. |- |align=center|about 1046 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[King Wu of Zhou|Wu]] establishes '''[[Zhou dynasty]]''' in [[China]]. [[Fenghao]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1047 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Saul|Shaul ben Qysh]] establishes the '''[[United Kingdom of Israel and Judah]]'''. [[Gibeah]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1070 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Nesbanebdjed I]] establishes the '''[[Twenty-first Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Tanis]] becomes the capital. |- |align=center|about 1077 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|The New Kingdom of Egypt collapses, beginning the [[Third Intermediate Period of Egypt]] |- |align=center|about 1184 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Greeks]] destroy the city-state of '''[[Troy]]'''. |- |align=center|about 1188 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Setnakhte]] establishes the '''[[Twentieth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Pi-Ramesses Aa-nakhtu]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 1243 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Ashur-nadin-apli]] of the '''[[Middle Assyrian Empire]]''' moves capital back to [[Assur]]. |- |align=center|about 1230 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Ramesses II]] builds a new capital for the '''[[Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]''' at the site of [[Avaris]] and names it [[Pi-Ramesses Aa-nakhtu]]. |- |align=center|about 1243 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Tukulti-Ninurta I]] of the '''[[Middle Assyrian Empire]]''' moves capital to [[Kar-Tukulti-Ninurta]]. |- |align=center|about 1272 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Mursili III]] of the '''[[Hittite empire]]''' moves capital back to [[Hattusa]]. |- |align=center|about 1293 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Ramesses I]] establishes the '''[[Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 1295 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Muwatalli II]] of the '''[[Hittite empire]]''' moves capital to [[Tarhuntassa]]. |- |align=center|about 1332 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Tutankhamun]] of the '''[[Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]''' moves capital to [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]]. |- |align=center|about 1340 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Ashur-uballit I]] establishes the '''[[Middle Assyrian Empire]]'''. [[Assur]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1345 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Akhenaten]] of the '''[[Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]''' moves capital to [[Amarna]] (Akhetaton). |- |align=center|about 1400 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Kurigalzu I]] a [[Kassites|Kassite]] king in Mesopotamia moves the capital to [[Dur-Kurigalzu]]. |- |align=center|about 1534 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Agum II]] establishes the rule of the '''[[Kassites]]''' in Mesopotamia. [[Babylon]] becomes the capital. |- |align=center|about 1534 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Pharaoh]] [[Ahmose I]] establishes the '''[[Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 1550 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|The [[New Kingdom of Egypt]] is established |- |align=center|about 1600 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Tang of Shang|Tang]] establishes the '''[[Shang dynasty]]''' in [[China]]. [[Yinxu]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1619 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Rahotep Sekhenrewahkhaw]] establishes the '''[[Seventeenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 1620 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Djehuti]] establishes the '''[[Sixteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1624 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Salitis]] establishes the '''[[Fifteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Avaris]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1650 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|The Middle Kingdom of Egypt collapses, beginning the [[Second Intermediate Period of Egypt]] |- |align=center|about 1710 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Nehesy]] establishes the '''[[Fourteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Xois]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1763 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Hammurabi]] establishes the '''[[Babylonian Empire]]'''. [[Babylon]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 1778 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Wegaf Khutawyre]] establishes the '''[[Thirteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Amenemhat-itj-tawy]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 1810 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Sumu-Epuh]] first attested king of the empire of '''[[Yamhad]]'''. [[Aleppo]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1894 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Sumu-abum]] establishes the '''[[First Babylonian Dynasty]]'''. [[Babylon]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1900 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Zulilu]] establishes the '''[[Old Assyrian Empire]]'''. [[Assur]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 1940 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|The Third Dynasty of Ur falls after an [[Elam]]ite invasion |- |align=center|about 1983 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Amenemhat I]] establishes the '''[[Twelfth Dynasty of Egypt]]''' and builds [[Amenemhat-itj-tawy]] to be the new capital. |} ===Third Millennium BCE=== {|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !style="width:5%"|Year||style="width:95%"|Event |- |align=center|about 2047 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Ur-Nammu]] establishes the '''[[Sumer]]ian [[Third Dynasty of Ur]]'''. [[Ur]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 2055 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|The [[Middle Kingdom of Egypt]] is established. |- |align=center|about 2070 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Yu the Great]] establishes the '''[[Xia dynasty]]''' in [[China]]. [[Dengfeng|Yangcheng]], [[Zhenxun]] are the capitals. |- |align=center|about 2112 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Utu-hengal]] defeats the [[Gutian people|Gutians]] and establishes the '''[[Third Dynasty of Ur]]'''. |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="2"|about 2130 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Mentuhotep I]] establishes the '''[[Eleventh Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]] becomes the capital of '''[[Upper Egypt]]'''. |- | style="background:#dfd;"|[[Meryhathor]] establishes the '''[[Tenth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Herakleopolis Magna|Henen-nesut]] remains the capital of '''[[Lower Egypt]]'''. |- |align=center|about 2160 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Meryibre Khety]] establishes the '''[[Ninth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Herakleopolis Magna|Henen-nesut]] becomes the capital of '''[[Lower Egypt]]'''. |- |align=center|about 2165 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Neferkare Pepiseneb]] establishes the '''[[Eighth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 2175 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Netjerkare]] establishes the '''[[Seventh Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 2181 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|The '''[[Old Kingdom of Egypt]]''' collapses, beginning the '''[[First Intermediate Period of Egypt]]'''. |- |align=center|about 2193 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"| The '''[[Akkadian Empire]]''' collapses after an invasion by the '''[[Gutians|Gutian people]]'''. |- |align=center|about 2270 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Sargon of Akkad]] establishes the '''[[Sumer]]ian [[Akkadian Empire|First Dynasty of Akkad]]''' after defeating [[Lugal-zage-si]] at the [[Battle of Uruk]]. [[Akkad (city)|Akkad]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 2333 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Dangun Wanggeom]] establishes '''[[Gojoseon]]''' on the [[Korean Peninsula]]. |- |align=center|about 2380 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Ur-Nanshe]] establishes the '''[[Sumer]]ian [[Lagash|First Dynasty of Lagash]]'''. [[Lagash]] is the capital. |- |align=center|about 2336 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Teti]] establishes the '''[[Sixth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 2484 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Userkaf]] establishes the '''[[Fifth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 2580 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|[[Mesannepada]] establishes the '''[[Sumerian king list#First dynasty of Ur|First Dynasty of Ur]]'''. [[Ur]] becomes the [[de facto]] capital of '''[[Sumer]]'''. |- |align=center|about 2655 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Sneferu]] establishes the '''[[Fourth Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. |- |align=center|about 2686 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|The '''[[Old Kingdom of Egypt]]''' is established. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. This era sees the building of the [[Egyptian pyramids]]. |- |align=center|about 2727 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Djoser]] establishes the '''[[Third Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] becomes the capital. |- |align=center|about 2860 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Hotepsekhemwy]] establishes the '''[[Second Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] remains the capital. |} ===Fourth Millennium BCE=== {|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !style="width:5%"|Year||style="width:95%"|Event |- |align=center|about 3080 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|[[Narmer]] (or [[Menes]]) unites '''[[Lower Egypt]]''' and '''[[Upper Egypt]]''' under the '''[[First Dynasty of Egypt]]'''. [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] becomes the capital of all [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. |- |align=center|about 3200 BCE|| style="background:#dfd;"|The regional power centers of '''[[Thinis]]''', '''[[Naqada]]''', and '''[[Nekhen]]''' dominate [[Upper Egypt]]. |- |align=center|about 3200 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|The [[city-state]]s of '''[[Eridu]]''', '''[[Bad-tibira]]''', '''[[Larsa]]''', '''[[Sippar]]''', and '''[[Shuruppak]]''' rise to prominence in [[Sumer]]. |} ===Tenth Millennium BCE=== {|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !style="width:5%"|Year||style="width:95%"|Event |- |align=center|about 9000 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|First stone structures at '''[[Jericho]]''' are built. |- |align=center|about 9500 BCE|| style="background:#fee;"|Building begins at '''[[Göbekli Tepe]]'''. |} ==See also== {{Lists of capitals}} *[[List of sovereign states by date of formation]] *[[List of former sovereign states]] *[[commons:Category:Blank maps of the world for historical use|Blank maps of the world for historical use]] *[[List of administrative division name changes]] *[[List of city name changes]] *[[List of national border changes since World War I]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{clear}} ==External links== {{sister project links|country}} {{Wikidata property|P17}} {{Lists of countries and territories by continent}} {{Territorial evolution of the world}} [[Category:National histories| ]] [[Category:Timelines by country| ]] [[Category:Territorial evolution| ]] [[Category:Maps]] [[Category:Geography-related lists]] [[Category:Cartography]] [[Category:History-related lists]]

{{Infobox person | name = Urbano Monti | image = Urbano Monti.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | residence = | known_for = | notable_works = | net_worth = | spouse = | children = | website = | alma mater = }}
'''Urbano Monti''' (1544–1613) (alternate spelling: '''Urbano Monte''') was an Italian cartographer.
== Life ==
He was born on 16 August 1544.<ref name="treccani.it">{{cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/urbano-monti_(Dizionario-Biografico)/|title=MONTI, Urbano in "Dizionario Biografico"|website=www.treccani.it|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref>
He was born and raised in Milan, Italy.<ref name="treccani.it"/>
He died on 15 May 1613.<ref name="treccani.it"/>
== Career ==
His most famous work is the Planisphere.
[[File:MontiPlanisphere.jpg|thumb|right|Monti's Planisphere]]
Some of his best known works are a part of the David Rumsey Map Collection of Stanford University and have been recently digitized.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.davidrumsey.com/blog/2017/11/26/largest-early-world-map-monte-s-10-ft-planisphere-of-1587|title=David Rumsey Map Collection|first=David|last=Rumsey|website=www.davidrumsey.com|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://it.businessinsider.com/la-piu-grande-mappa-del-mondo-ai-tempi-del-rinascimento-video/?refresh_ce|title=La più grande mappa del mondo ai tempi del Rinascimento – video|date=15 January 2018|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref>
== Bibliography ==
His notable books include:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/search.php?query=creator%3A%22Urbano+Monte+%28Monti%29%22 |title=Internet Archive Search: creator:"Urbano Monte (Monti)" |publisher=Archive.org |date=2017-12-17 |accessdate=2018-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-no96063096/ |title=Descrizione del mondo sin qui conosciuto / |publisher=Worldcat.org |date= |accessdate=2018-05-31}}</ref>
* Descrizione del mondo sin qui conosciuto
* Un prezioso cimelio della cartografia italiana
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links ==
* [https://archive.org/details/UrbanoMontemonti1544-1613] * [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/urbano-monti_(Dizionario-Biografico)/]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Monti, Urbano}}

revision.comment: /* Elm Allée */ add link Princeton Nurseries
revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name =Washington Road Elm Allée | nrhp_type =nrhp | image =Washington Road Elm Allée (east side).jpg | caption =The easternmost of the triple allées, facing south toward [[U.S. Route 1 in New Jersey|U.S. Route One]] | location= [[County Route 571 (New Jersey)|Washington Road]] between the [[Delaware and Raritan Canal]] and [[U.S. Route 1 in New Jersey|U.S. Route One]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|20|04.8|N|74|38|31.7|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = USA New Jersey Mercer County#New Jersey#USA | area = {{convert|6|acre}} | built =planted mid-1920s | architect= Princeton nurseries | architecture=[[Tree Avenue or tree alley (allée)|Tree avenue]] | added = January 14, 1999 | governing_body = [[Princeton University]] | refnum=98001571 | designated_other1_name = New Jersey Register of Historic Places | designated_other1_abbr = NJRHP | designated_other1_link = New Jersey Register of Historic Places | designated_other1_date = November 12, 1998 | designated_other1_number = 3291<ref name=NJRHP>{{cite web | title=New Jersey and National Registers of Historic Places: Mercer County | url=http://www.nj.gov/dep/hpo/1identify/nrsr_lists/mercer.pdf | publisher=[[New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection]] Historic Preservation Office | date= January 2, 2015}}</ref> | designated_other1_num_position = bottom | designated_other1_color = #ffc94b }}
The '''Washington Road Elm Allée''' is a {{convert|0.7|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}} stretch of [[County Route 571 (New Jersey)|Washington Road]] in [[West Windsor, New Jersey]] that is lined with [[Ulmus americana 'Princeton'|Princeton Elm]] trees. The allée runs through the West Windsor fields of [[Princeton University]] and provides, along with the bridge over [[Lake Carnegie (New Jersey)|Lake Carnegie]], a dramatic entrance to the campus. The [[Delaware and Raritan Canal]] can be found at the northern end of the allée, just before the lake. A jogging path runs through the allée and connects to the canal [[towpath]], the main campus of the university, and other trails through the adjacent fields.
==History==
===Elm Allée===
[[File:Washington Road Elm Allee.JPG|thumb|left]]
The original allée was planted in the mid-1920s by [[Princeton Nurseries]], at one time the country's largest commercial [[plant nursery]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Offredo|first1=Jon|title=Former Princeton Nurseries celebrates 100th anniversary in Kingston|url=http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2013/09/former_princeton_nurseries_celebrates_100th_anniversary_in_kingston.html|newspaper=The Trenton Times|date=September 6, 2013}}</ref> The Elm trees are of the Princeton variety, developed by Princeton Nurseries for its landscaping quality, and are resistant to [[Dutch elm disease]], the only one of ten resistant cultivars to have trees that have reached maturity.<ref name=Brookes>{{cite web |last=Brookes |first=A.H. |title=Disease-resistant elm cultivars, Butterfly Conservation trials report, 3rd revision |date=2013 |work= |publisher=Butterfly Conservation |location=Lulworth UK |url=http://www.hantsiow-butterflies.org.uk/conservation/2013%20Elm%20Report%20Sept%202013.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> Of the original 136 Elms planted in the 1920s only 76 survive. They are approximately {{convert|24-26|in}} in diameter and {{convert|60|ft}} tall. Their branches meet over the roadway to provide a leafy canopy. The allée has many replacement trees, including 16 [[Acer platanoides|Norway maples]] planted in the 1960s, and 31 [[Ulmus americana 'American Liberty'|Liberty elms]] planted in 1995. The secondary rows of [[Ulmus americana 'Delaware'|Delaware Elms]] were planted in 1983, and a long row of [[forsythia]] to the east is thought to date from the late 1960s.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hand|first1=Susanne C.|title=Washington Road Elm Allée|url={{NRHP url|id=98001571}}|website=National Register of Historic Places|publisher=National Park Service}}</ref>
===Schenck-Covenhoven Burial Ground===
[[File:Schenck-Covenhoven Burial Yard.jpg|thumb|left|The cemetery, as seen from the Elm Allée]]
To the east of the Elm Allée, {{convert|1100|ft}} from the road, along the jogging path, can be found the '''Schenck-Covenhoven Burial Ground''', sometimes called the '''Old Conover Graveyard'''. It contains forty or fifty graves surrounded by a stone wall and is undoubtedly the oldest cemetery in West Windsor Township, with burials dating to at least 1751. The Schenck and Covenhoven families were [[Dutch people|Dutch]] farmers who purchased {{convert|6000|acre}} in what is now West Windsor from [[William Penn]] in 1737.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of the Township of West Windsor|url=http://www.westwindsornj.org/history.html|publisher=Township of West Windsor, Mercer County, New Jersey}}</ref> The Conover family was among the original settlers in [[Penns Neck, New Jersey|Penns Neck]], a settlement found at the south end of the allée.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Woodward|first1=Major E.M.|last2=Hageman|first2=John F.|title=History of Burlington and Mercer Counties, New Jersey, with Biographical Sketches of Many of Their Pioneers and Prominent Men|date=1883|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~njmercer/Mun/WWindHis.htm}}</ref> The cemetery has been in disuse for more than a century, though it receives some maintenance from the university.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Frederick|first1=Wilhelmina Schenck|title=The Schenck-Covenhoven Burial Ground on the Jewell Farm at Penns Neck|date=November 21, 1938|publisher=Historical Society of Princeton|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Schenck_Covenhoven_Burial_Ground_on.html?id=nJzEoAEACAAJ}}</ref>
